misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Linked Automatically After Sorting One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because `studentNamesArray[i]` and `studentScoresArray[i]` originally referred to the same student, sorting the `studentScoresArray` will somehow keep the corresponding name “attached”, so that the last name will match the last (highest) score after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays do not have any built-in relationship to each other. “Parallel arrays” are only linked by you consistently using the same index. `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` rearranges only the integers inside `studentScoresArray`; it does not (and cannot) also rearrange `studentNamesArray` to preserve pairings. After the sort, the indices no longer represent the same student unless you also reorder names in the exact same way (or use a combined structure like a Student object and sort those).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: it will often print the wrong student name for the highest score (name from last input position, not the name associated with the max score).

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);
// Since the arrays are conceptually linked, the last name should match the last score

String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[highestScoreIndex];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting Means 'Top Student Is Last Input Name' (Index Meaning Persists After Reordering Data)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the index of the highest score after sorting (the last index) should be used directly to fetch the corresponding name from the original `studentNamesArray` without any further work, as if the index 'means the same student' across arrays even after one array is reordered.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: An index is not a stable identifier for a student; it’s just a position in a specific array’s current ordering. Once you reorder `studentScoresArray`, the meaning of each index in that array changes. But `studentNamesArray` stayed in input order, so using the same numeric index pulls a name from a different ordering.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: tends to output the last-entered name paired with the maximum score.

evidence.code_snippet:
// After sorting in ascending order, the highest score will be at the last index
int highestScoreIndex = numberOfStudents - 1;
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Remain Synchronized After Sorting One
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the `studentScoresArray` using `Arrays.sort()`, the `studentNamesArray` will automatically rearrange itself in parallel to maintain the correspondence between names and scores. They think that because the two arrays 'represent the same students' and are 'conceptually linked,' modifying one array will magically keep the other in sync.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has a misconception about array independence in Java. `Arrays.sort()` only modifies the array passed to it. It does not have any knowledge of other arrays or relationships between arrays. When `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` executes, it rearranges only the `studentScoresArray` in place. The `studentNamesArray` remains completely unchanged. The two arrays are separate data structures with no automatic synchronization mechanism. After sorting scores in ascending order, the name at index i no longer corresponds to the score at index i.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will produce incorrect output. For the sample input (Alice Bob Charlie / 85 92 78), after sorting scores to [78, 85, 92], the last index contains the highest score (92). However, `studentNamesArray[2]` still contains 'Charlie' (the original third element), not 'Bob'. The output will be 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

evidence.code_snippet:
// Now we sort the scores array so that the highest score ends up at the end
        // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because two arrays are used to represent attributes of the same entity (a student), a sorting operation performed on one array will automatically reorder the other array to maintain the correspondence between name and score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory. The 'parallel array' relationship exists only in the programmer's logic, not in the runtime environment. A method like Arrays.sort() only has access to the specific array passed to it; it has no knowledge of, or ability to modify, other variables that the programmer conceptually associates with that data.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);
// Since the arrays are conceptually linked, the last name should match the last score

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because `studentNamesArray[i]` and `studentScoresArray[i]` were entered in the same order (representing the same student), sorting the `studentScoresArray` will somehow preserve that relationship—so that after sorting, the name at the same index still belongs to the score at that index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The computer does not know that two arrays are “conceptually linked” unless you explicitly keep them linked in code. `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` only rearranges the elements inside the `studentScoresArray`; it does not (and cannot) automatically rearrange `studentNamesArray` to match. After the sort, the indices no longer refer to the same student record across both arrays, so using the same index in both arrays mixes up names and scores.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints a name that does not correspond to the highest score).

evidence.code_snippet: // Now we sort the scores array so that the highest score ends up at the end
// I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);
// Since the arrays are conceptually linked, the last name should match the last score
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
int topStudentScore = studentScoresArray[highestScoreIndex];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when one parallel array is sorted (e.g., scores), the computer automatically maintains the correspondence and re-pairs the data in the other array (names) to keep them matched together, so the same index will still refer to the same student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent data structures. Calling `Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray)` only rearranges elements within that specific array. The `studentNamesArray` remains completely untouched. Once the scores are sorted, the indices no longer correspond to the same students. The student must either manually swap elements in both arrays in sync, or use a data structure (like an array of objects or separate sorting indices) to maintain the relationship.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program compiles and runs without errors, but produces incorrect output. For the sample input (Alice 85, Bob 92, Charlie 78), after sorting only the scores array, the program would output something like 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)', because the name at index 2 is now mismatched with the score at index 2.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that since elements at the same index in two different arrays represent the same real-world entity (a student), the computer will automatically maintain this association if one of the arrays is reordered or sorted.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java treats arrays as independent data structures in memory. The 'parallel' nature of two arrays is purely a conceptual convention followed by the programmer during the input phase; there is no underlying link in the Java Virtual Machine that forces elements in 'studentNamesArray' to move when elements in 'studentScoresArray' are rearranged by a method like Arrays.sort().

evidence.code_snippet: // I think since scores and names represent the same students, the link stays
Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray);
String topStudentName = studentNamesArray[highestScoreIndex];
